title: 114_hr2712
content: The "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes provisions for a prospective reporting system and protection of dependent privacy. Congress aims to minimize compliance burdens under the Affordable Care Act while balancing the need for sufficient reporting and individual privacy. The Act mandates the implementation of a voluntary prospective reporting system by the Treasury Secretary within 180 days of enactment. Employers can report essential coverage details for full-time employees through this system. The Act mandates a voluntary prospective reporting system for employers to report coverage details for full-time employees, including whether coverage is offered to dependents, spouses, part-time employees, meets minimum value requirements, satisfies affordability safe harbors, availability to full-time employees, and any applicable waiting periods. The Act requires employers to report coverage details for full-time employees, including waiting periods, securely accessed by Exchanges and IRS for eligibility determinations. The Affordable Care Act requires employers to report employee eligibility information for advance payment subsidies and cost-sharing subsidies. Employers must also provide updates to the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub regarding changes in coverage for participating employees. Employers meeting reporting requirements are exempt from certain IRS reporting requirements for the calendar year. Employers must report employee eligibility information for subsidies under the Affordable Care Act. They are exempt from certain IRS reporting requirements if they provide the necessary statements to the IRS and employees who have enrolled in a qualified health plan through the Exchange. Employers can use third parties for filing tax credits and subsidies under the Affordable Care Act. Exchanges must notify employers when an employee enrolls in a qualified health plan. SEC. 4 amends Section 6055(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow substitution of name and date of birth for TINs if not collected before 2014. SEC. 5 relates to electronic statements. Section 6056(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow electronic delivery of statements if consent has been given by the individual's employer. Similarly, Section 6055(c) is amended to allow electronic delivery of health insurance coverage statements if prior consent for electronic health information has been given. The amendments made by this section allow electronic delivery of health information if consent is given, effective for statements due after December 31, 2015. The amendments allow electronic delivery of health information with consent, effective for statements due after December 31, 2015. GAO studies. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study evaluating employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act from January 1, 2014, to December 31, 2016, regarding eligibility for tax credits and subsidies. The study will evaluate employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act from 2014 to 2016, focusing on the process, sufficiency of information, total notifications sent, differences between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, challenges, and recommendations. The Comptroller General will evaluate employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act from 2014 to 2016, focusing on the notification process, challenges, recommendations, and appeals process for employers. A report on the study results will be submitted to relevant committees within a year of the Act's enactment. Additionally, a study will be conducted to evaluate a prospective reporting system. The Comptroller General will evaluate the functionality of the prospective reporting system established under section 3, including the accuracy of information collected, employer participation, and implementation challenges. A report on the study results will be submitted to relevant committees by July 1, 2018. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION PROCESS FOR ACA SUBSIDIES. A marketplace can automatically reenroll an individual in a qualified health plan if eligibility for subsidies is redetermined annually, considering changes in premiums and income. If the marketplace lacks current income information, reenrollment with subsidies is not allowed until the individual provides the necessary details. The marketplace can automatically reenroll individuals in a qualified health plan if eligibility for subsidies is redetermined annually. Reenrollment with subsidies is not allowed until current income information is provided. The provisions in this section align with guidance on annual eligibility redeterminations and reenrollments issued by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. Enrollees receiving credit or cost-sharing reduction must authorize disclosure of information for verification. The marketplace must request updated income annually for eligibility verification and provide timely notices for redeterminations and reenrollments. The term "marketplace" refers to State Based Exchanges and the Federally Facilitated Exchange under the Affordable Care Act.
